pros: Great place to work. Good management.
cons: All bureaucracies have many levels of management and sometimes conflicting priorities.

pros: UAF used to be a great place to work: small university, supportive people, functioning infrastructure
cons: Most toxic workplace ever; rampant cronyism among upper administration; competent deans and directors replaced over time by incompetent friends of the Provost and Chancellor; failed Grants and Contracts; superficial lip service to diversity and equity, but professional discrimination, discrimination against people of color and women runs deep under the surface; attacks against tenure, and academic freedom; absolutely failed Human Resources department; Provost is a micro-manager who retaliates against any faculty or staff who criticize her or the administration. Do not come here to work if you value academic freedom, the right to be your authentic self and are not self-serving, power hungry or amoral.

review_title: How to destroy a University - Hire useless and ignorant administrators.
pros: It is a nice small research university dedicated to high latitude research.
cons: The top level administration from Deans all the way up have no clues about academic / research systems and furthermore; they don't have a clue about the future in research and education. Nor even have a clue about what the student community wants and or how to stimulate them. Input from faculty and students are not even considered. I would say that what took more than 75 years of research to build an outstanding reputation mainly by the Geophysical Institute and the Institute of Arctic Biology have been destroyed in the last 10 years by useless Directors, VCR and upper level administration. An unfortunate pity!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairbanks, AK
pros: A good place to work. Friendly staff. Quiet environment.
cons: low salary and benefits. Health insurance is not good.

pros: It varies by department and supervisor, but overall this is a wonderful place to work

pros: Nice people and nice natural views

review_title: Great Place to work only If you are related to the Faculty.
pros:
Most Staff (Not Faculty) are friendly. 
Fairbanks is a Great town to live.
Friendly neighborhood.

Nepotism.

Management has zero interest in addressing real issues.

pros: Great campus atmosphere, good career opportunities, good higher education benefits

pros: Great professors. Good quality students help to keep the university research ongoing.
cons: Difficult to find a good postdoc who is willing to come to AK. And hiring is very slow especially for international postdocs. Difficult to boost a research lab to another level.

review_title: UAF-Community and Tech College a Toxic place
pros: The pay and benefits are fairly good.
cons: It's a toxic environment. When budget cuts were first initiated years ago, management and directors became paranoid they would be on the chopping block and made a long series of bad decisions. A lot of backstabbing. Trust between employees and confidence in leadership does not exist. There was a mass exodus of their best leaders and employees several years ago. Today the university is run by whoever couldn't move on to something better. The community supported the state making massive budget cuts to the university, cutting large numbers of faculty/staff and eliminating entire programs. It has become one of the worst universities in the nation by ranking. Locals only send their kids there if they can't get in anywhere else.

pros: Good life work balance here.
cons: Harsh weather in winter time.

cons: Very high overhead taken from external research dollars, needed to support the university due to frequent reductions in funding from the state of AK.

job_title: Career Services Coordinator in Fairbanks, AK
pros: I started as a student and after about a year of working hard and impressing the right people I was promoted from within to a full-time staff position. From what I understand this happens quite frequently. Student jobs give you excellent resume building starting experience and if you play your cards right you can develop great networking connections within the community. For the most part the organizational culture is pretty positive but it does depend heavily on what department you work for.
cons: The organizational culture can be toxic depending on where you work within the University and who your report to as is the case with any company. Right now we are also facing severe budget cuts with a lot of people leaving/losing jobs creating an increased workload on those left behind, again as with any other company out there.

review_title: UAF serves a vital role as an institution of higher learning in Alaska.
job_title: Communications Specialist IV in Fairbanks, AK
pros: In the department I work in my supervisor is very supportive of professional development and training. He is also willing to allow me some flexibility in my work schedule to accommodate other responsibilities in my life outside of work. I am satisfied with my benefits package and regularly take advantage of the tuition waiver available to employees. I feel fortunate and have heard accounts from UAF employees in other departments who may not have such a supportive supervisor.
cons: I think the expectations of my job are more than a single person can manage successfully and facing a shrinking budget situation in coming years, I think that will only get worse. I don't think the work environment is consistent across departments.

review_title: Good Employer, Great Benefits, Difficult Bureaucratic Environment
job_title: Technology Support Specialist in Fairbanks, AK
pros: Excellent employer, great benefits, good culture. Everyone is nice, is working towards the same goal (student success), and promote a healthy work culture by providing a fun (and diverse) working environment.
cons: Incredibly Bureaucratic. Takes forever to get tasks/projects/purchases processed or approved. Upper Management tends to have a communication disconnect between lower departments, limiting important information being passing up/down. Raises and bonuses were almost impossible to get. Benefits got worse recently after the Oil crisis hit.

review_title: Great place to work with great benefits, though your salary
job_title: Scientific Support Services in Fairbanks, AK
pros:
-Excellent location with great views from campus, if you are on the main Fairbanks campus.
-Generally relaxed, low-pressure work environment, though I'm sure this depends on whom you work with.
-Close to town, amazing (probably best in the world or close) system of cross-country and bike trails right behind university FREE - if you are into outdoors and not afraid of the cold, you will be in heaven and will never want to leave!
-Pretty decent benefits, including retirement.
-Generally flexible work environment, though this is supervisor-dependent I imagine.
-Impressively advanced IT and communications options on campus, tuition coverage.
cons:
-Salary is generally lower than in surrounding area though this is probably position-dependent, and probably does not apply if you are an upper level administrator or professor.
-Their HR is REALLY incompetent. It took me 2 months until I received my first paycheck when I first started working there and they once terminated me by accident when I was being switched to a different type of position within the university causing me to lose insurance and miss medical appointments. This is not uncommon, a few colleagues have had seven worse experiences.  
-Parking has become kind of insane lately in some areas of campus where they are doubling the cost of a parking decal pass to raise revenue, but there is a decent public transportation on campus (free to UAF employees!) and many bike or ski to work.

review_title: I enjoyed my time working for UAF.
pros: Everyone was laid back (in what I think of as the typical Fairbanks way), I never had any problems other than whether or not I was doing my job well. Since I was doing it well, it was low stress.
cons: The University of Alaska system's  (and the state of Alaska's) budget issues over shadowed my time working here. It was on the table that my entire department was going to get destroyed/centralized. It never happened, nor did it look like it was ever going to be too likely at any point in the proceedings, but the possibility was there.

pros: Most if not all people are very understanding and will help you in any way they can. Rather easy going work so long as the end goal is met which is completely understandable.
cons: Rather difficult to get in especially with recent cuts to the UA system as a whole, but this is more of a state issue rather than an issue with the company itself.

pros:
Great Travel 

Decent 401K and benefits

Many opportunities to learn from staff and researchers

Positive networking with other institutions

Exciting projects and work

Lots of experience in professional flexibility and efficiency
cons:
Credit for your work will be claimed by upper management, while blame rolls downhill to you

Hostile work environment around very tight deadlines

Pressure to work overtime without compensation

Museum HR was ineffectual in resolving complaints on multiple occasions

Very unpleasant and unprofessional exiting procedure.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Fairbanks, AK
pros: This really depends on what department you are working for. If you work for the Office of Admissions, you will work all of the time. If you work in a small department people seem to be happier and more satisfied with their work. My current office is fantastic. People are always trying new things and failure is ok.
cons:
-Budget cuts
-Too much higher level management
-Lack of entry and mid-level employee support

pros:
Free tuition for yourself and your dependents. 
Schedule can be flexible depending on position and department
Hires a wide range of positions in a small town
cons:
Pay can be low depending on your field - they under value IT people.
People in management positions can have little/no experience managing professional people and they are not required to take training. 
No system in place to handle bad managers
No upward mobility and little career security if you do not have tenure

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairbanks, AK
pros: I really enjoy the atmosphere at UAF. It is very relaxed and people are willing to help each other.
cons:
Small departments mean you will usually be working by yourself. There is generally a very limited amount of lab space. I was told to use a general purpose lab and had to pack up my equipment every night. This was very frustrating because I spent a lot of time organizing my equipment every day and not on my research.

Research funding is very tight in academia and I would not recommend this path to many people.

pros: The benefit package is okay compared to what other companies are offering in this area.
cons:
Even though they say that they are an equal opportunity employer, I regularly saw raises, promotions and hiring practices done that involved favoritism and finding loopholes around the hiring process. They would advertise job openings so that they could give a promotion to a specific individual, everyone else would apply and interview but it was already predetermined who would be hired into the position. The interview panel would always lean the questions in favor of the candidate that they wanted to hire or promote. Raises were given based on favoritism and not on merit and the performance reviews were just more paperwork to fill out without any real substance or measurable standards to attain.
The University keeps requiring more and more and more paperwork and reporting requirements year after year. People are so overloaded with STUFF to do that quality work is not being done and can never be done with the staff that they have. Then they layoff people but don't reduce any of the reporting or paperwork requirements.

review_title: Great people working together to bring IT to the University
pros: Great people.  Management is friendly and all the technicians and students work together well to get things done.  There are lots of opportunities for cross training between the different IT departments and opportunities to get professional IT certificates as well.
cons: IT support can be a little boring at times waiting around for instructors or students to come to you with problems.  Decision making via Upper Management can be slow which hinders how much work the technicians can get done.

review_title: UAF is going downhill from a staff perspective
pros:
Benefits (tuition, health incentives)
Flexibility (depending on supervisor)
Stimulating environment
One of the biggest employers, and once you're "in the system" you can move within it
cons:
Medical benefit costs have doubled for most staff
Starting wages are lower and lower every year
Parking is expensive and challenging
Pay scales and evaluation procedures are very uneven among employees with similar responsibilities (see the Sun Star Salary Publication from 2011- a total shock!)

review_title: An awesome job for graduate students
pros: Stipend is generous (comparing to the school where I received my undergraduate degree), and have reasonable working hours. Also, T.As pays no tuition fee for the first 10 credits hours in each semester because the department pays for them.
cons: Some professors aren't friendly to me. I am glad that my "boss" (the professor I am working with) is genuine and passionate to his students.

job_title: Graduate Student in South Fairbanks, AK
pros: I got to travel across Alaska, and the rest of the US and Canada. There is also a lot of funding sources for research. Loved my advisor and fellowship cohort. Great place to learn and explore.
cons: Fairbanks can be cold and feel isolated. The water on campus is really gross. Also, housing is expensive.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fairbanks, AK
pros: Working environment is very good and the faculty is very helpful. I am getting to learn a lot of things during my work. Good salary.
cons: Sometimes too much workload in the weekdays. Sometimes have to work even after coming back to home

review_title: Good place for grad school if highly self-motivated
pros: Reasonable compensation for graduate teaching assistants, basic health insurance and tuition waiver.  Excellent facilities for biology in new building.  Supportive administration.
cons: High cost of living in Fairbanks, culture perhaps a bit too laid back. Budgetary woes with AK's recent financial shortfalls.  Difficulty retaining talented faculty. Top-heavy administration.

pros: The benefits are the only redeeming part about this job.   Tuition reimbursement
cons: Low pay for the amount of work you do, no chance of getting longer hours, supervisors are generally 18 year old who just did their original job good enough but have no clue on how to manage people.

pros: It was really nice to work for UAF chemistry department.  I was also a TA at the school in the chemistry department.   I can't speak for other departments.
cons: Of course, adjunct pay is not for long term work.  But that goes for any school.
